user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_CondVarTimedWait_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_CondVarTimedWait_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token, const OS_time_t *abs_wakeup_time)
{
    struct timespec                    limit;
    int                                status;
    OS_impl_condvar_internal_record_t *impl;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_condvar_table, *token);

    limit.tv_sec  = OS_TimeGetTotalSeconds(*abs_wakeup_time);
    limit.tv_nsec = OS_TimeGetNanosecondsPart(*abs_wakeup_time);

    pthread_cleanup_push(OS_Posix_CondVarReleaseMutex, &impl->mut);
    status = pthread_cond_timedwait(&impl->cv, &impl->mut, &limit);
    pthread_cleanup_pop(false);

    if (status == ETIMEDOUT)
    {
        return OS_ERROR_TIMEOUT;
    }
    if (status != 0)
    {
        return OS_ERROR;
    }

    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_CondVarTimedWait_Impl:
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
OS_impl_condvar_internal_record_t OS_impl_condvar_table[OS_MAX_CONDVARS]
...
typedef struct
{
    pthread_mutex_t mut;
    pthread_cond_t  cv;
} OS_impl_condvar_internal_record_t
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
typedef struct
{
    int64 ticks; /**< Ticks elapsed since reference point */
} OS_time_t
...
#define OS_ERROR_TIMEOUT (-4)
...
#define OS_ERROR (-1)
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No compiler language extensions are used in the provided function. The code uses standard C constructs and POSIX pthread APIs: local variables, structure access, array indexing via the OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET macro, calls to pthread_cond_timedwait and pthread_cleanup_push/pop, and standard error constant checks. None of the following are present and thus do not need investigation for Rule 1.2: • GCC/Clang-specific extensions (e.g., __attribute__, __asm__, __extension__, typeof, statement-expressions ({ ... })) • Compiler-specific keywords or builtins. • Any inline assembly or vendor-specific pragmas. Note on pthread_cleanup_push/pop: these are POSIX thread macros (library-level), not compiler language extensions as defined by compiler documentation; their use is permitted under Rule 1.2 unless a particular toolchain documents them as a compiler extension. The boolean literal false is a standard identifier from <stdbool.h> in C99 and later; its use is not a compiler extension. All other macros and typedefs shown (OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET, OS_impl_condvar_table, OS_time_t, OS_ERROR_*, etc.) are project-defined and do not by themselves constitute compiler language extensions.
